TrueFalseQuestion.text: Global Scratch variables can be used by different sprites.
A Scratch variable with value 1 cannot be a boolean variable.
In Scratch, a local variable can be used by one or two different sprites.
A Scratch variable can have value -1.
The value of a global Scratch variable can only be changed one time.
In Scratch, a local variable can only be used by one script.
Each Scratch sprite may have no more than one script.
The same event can be received by different Scratch sprites.
The same event can be broadcast by different Scratch sprites.
In Scratch, a single script can broadcast multiple events.
In Excel, a function can be used in the argument of another function.
The \code{blink} tag is no longer an officially supported HTML tag. (And that's a good thing.)
An HTML \code{title} tag belongs inside the \code{head} tag.
An HTML \code{head} tag belongs inside the \code{body} tag.
A webpage's \code{html} tag must contain attributes or the page won't load.
Most web browsers will do their best to load a webpage with incorrectly-placed tags.
The \code{border} attribute for the HTML \code{table} tag determines whether lines around the table and the individual cells will be displayed.
The most appropriate way to change \textbf{how} text in a webpage is displayed is with the \code{font} tag.

The following HTML code will change the entire page background to orange.
\code{<style>\\ \codeIndent body \{background-color:orange;\}\\ </style> }
An HTML node can have multiple style classes.

ExamQuestionGroup.header: Consider this Scratch script:\\ \code{wait 1 secs\\ if catMonkey = 0\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{I'm hungry} for 2 secs\\ else\\ \codeIndent wait 2 secs\\ wait 2 secs\\}

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: If \code{catMonkey} only ever has value 0 or 1, what is \code{catMonkey} called?
How will the time it takes this script to run be affected if the value of \code{catMonkey} is changed from 0 to 1?
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: Probably by increasing it by slightly more than 1 second.
Probably by increasing it by slightly more than 2 seconds.

ExamQuestionGroup.header: Consider this Scratch script:\\ \code{set mouse to 0\\ repeat until mouse + 1 = 10\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{I like mice!} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent wait 1 secs\\ \codeIndent change mouse by 1\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{I like mice!} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent wait 1 secs}

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: How many times will the sprite say: I like mice!
What will the value of mouse be when the script ends?
Approximately how long does this script take to run?
What would happen if the instruction \code{change mouse by 1} is replaced with \code{change mouse by 2}?
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: The script would run in slightly over 10 seconds.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.answer: The script would run in slightly over 18 seconds.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: The script does run at all.
The script runs forever (or until the user stops it).
All three do the same thing

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text:
Which of the following Scratch code snippets do the same thing?
\begin{itemize} \item[1:] \code{gibbon = 0\\ repeat until gibbon > 10\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{This is a long song...} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{It keeps going on and on...} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{But it's not that other terrible song!} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent set gibbon to gibbon - 1} \item[2:] \code{barracuda = 0\\ repeat until barracuda > 100\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{This is a long song...} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{It keeps going on and on...} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{But it's not that other terrible song!} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent change barracuda by 1} \item[3:] \code{forever\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{This is a long song...} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{It keeps going on and on...} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{But it's not that other terrible song!} for 1 secs} \end{itemize}
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: All three do the same thing

MultipleChoiceQuestion.answer: She could use either; they both work.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: Neither of them would help her answer the questions.

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text:
Which of the following sets of Scratch scripts will do the same thing when the \code{bananaman} event is broadcast?
\begin{itemize} \item[1:] \code{when I receive \fbox{bananaman}\\ say \fbox{I wanna be a monkey!} for 1 secs\\ broadcast \fbox{badgerBadger}\\ \phantom{a}\\ when I receive \fbox{badgerBadger}\\ say \fbox{a monkey monkey monkey!} for 1 secs\\ broadcast \fbox{bananaman}} \item[2:] \code{when I receive \fbox{bananaman}\\ forever\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{I wanna be a monkey!} for 1 secs\\ \codeIndent broadcast \fbox{badgerBadger}\\ \codeIndent say \fbox{a monkey monkey monkey!} for 1 secs} \item[3:] \code{when I receive \fbox{bananaman}\\ say \fbox{I wanna be a monkey!} for 1 secs\\ broadcast \fbox{badgerBadger}\\ \phantom{a}\\ when I receive \fbox{badgerBadger}\\ say \fbox{a monkey monkey monkey!} for 1 secs} \end{itemize}
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: All three do the same thing

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: Which of the following is the \code{PMT} function used for?
MultipleChoiceQuestion.answer: To determine the payments that will need to be made to pay off a loan.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: To determine the current value of an investment based on constant payments and interest rate.
To determine the future value of an investment with constant payments and interest rate.
To determine the power of monkey theology based on constant loan payments.

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: Which of the following is the \code{FV} function used for?
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: To determine the current value of an investment based on constant payments and interest rate.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.answer: To determine the future value of an investment with constant payments and interest rate.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: To determine the payments that will need to be made to pay off a loan.
To determine the future value of an investment based on gibbon murals.

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: Which of the following is the \code{PV} function used for?
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: To determine the future value of an investment with constant payments and interest rate.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.answer: To determine the current value of an investment based on constant payments and interest rate.
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: To determine the payments that will need to be made to pay off a loan.
To determine the number of orangutans needed to power a vacuum.

ExamQuestionGroup.header:
Consider this Excel table:
\begin{tabular}{l|c|c|c|} & A & B & C \\ \hline 1 & 70 & 90 & \\ \hline 2 & 90 & 70 & \\ \hline 3 & 100 & 100 & \\ \hline 4 & 60 & 100 & \\ \hline 5 & 80 & 80 & \\ \hline 6 & & & \\ \hline \end{tabular}

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: What will be displayed in cell C1 if the formula \code{=MAX(AVERAGE(A1:B1), .25*A1 + .75*B1)} is entered there?
What will the formula be in cell C2 if cell C1 is copied there?
What will be displayed in cell C5 if the formula from C1 is copied and pasted into the cells C2, C3, C4 and C5?

ExamQuestionGroup.header:
Consider this Excel table:
\begin{tabular}{l|c|c|c|} & A & B & C \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 20 & \\ \hline 2 & 10 & 6 & \\ \hline 3 & -5 & 1 & \\ \hline 4 & 0 & -10 & \\ \hline \end{tabular}

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: What will be displayed in cell C1 if the formula \code{=IF(A1>B1, 1, -1)} is entered there?
What will the formula be in cell C2 if cell C1 is copied there?
If the formula from cell C1 is copied into C2, C3 and C4, what will be displayed in C4?
Next, what will be displayed in C5 then if the formula \code{=COUNTIF(C1:C4, > 0)} is entered there?

ExamQuestionGroup.header:
Consider this Excel table:
\begin{tabular}{l|c|c|} & A & B \\ \hline 1 & 5 & 4 \\ \hline 2 & -2 & 2 \\ \hline 3 & -1 & -2 \\ \hline 4 & 3 & 8 \\ \hline 5 & -2 & 5 \\ \hline 6 & & \\ \hline \end{tabular}

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: What will be displayed in cell A6 if the formula \code{=MAX(A1:A5)} is entered there?
What will be displayed in cell A6 if the formula \code{=COUNTIF(A1:A5, > 0)} is entered there?
What will be displayed in cell B6 if the formula \code{=SUMIF(A1:A5, > 0, B1:B5)} is entered there?
What will be displayed in cell B6 if the formula \code{=IF(SUM(A1:A5) > 5, MAX(B1:B5), SUM(B1:B5))} is entered there?

ExamQuestionGroup.header:
Consider this Excel table:
\begin{tabular}{l|c|c|c|c|c|} & A & B & C & D & E\\ \hline 1 & 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & \\ \hline 2 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 & \\ \hline 3 & 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & \\ \hline \end{tabular}

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: What will be displayed in cell E1 if the formula \code{=COUNTIF(A1:D1, > 5)} is entered there?
What will be displayed in cell E2 if the formula \code{=COUNTIF(A2:D2, > 5)} is entered there?
What will be displayed in cell E3 if the formula \code{=COUNTIF(A1:D3, > 5)} is entered there?
What will be displayed in cell E3 if the formula \code{=IF(COUNTIF(A1:D3, > 5) > 6, 100, 4)} is entered there?
Which of the following snippets of HTML creates a link to the site \url{monkeys.com} with the text: \code{awesome page}?
Which of the following snippets of HTML creates a bulleted list?

Which table will the following HTML produce? \code{\\ \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \\
MonkeyGibbon
Mankey
Primeape
}
Which is the correct way to create an HTML table?

Which table is produced by the following HTML snippet? \code{\\ \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \\
\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent
AB
CD
\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent		\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent \\ \codeIndent \codeIndent \codeIndent
EF
GH
\\ \codeIndent \codeIndent
}
Which of the following HTML snippets uses the correct syntax to create a style class usable by multiple types of tags?
Where can HTML styles be defined?
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice: In a style attribute in an HTML tag.
Inside the document, defined in a \code{style} tag within the \code{head} tag.

MultipleChoiceQuestion.text: Which of the following will create a new text-input box in a web form?
Which of the following will cause a window to pop up saying the text \code{Monkey!}?
Which of the following HTML snippets will create a web form with a button labelled "Click Me!"?
Which of the following HTML snippets correctly creates a radio button group for use in a web form?
MultipleChoiceQuestion.answer:
\code{Are you a college student?
\\ \codeIndent Yes
\\ \codeIndent No
}
MultipleChoiceQuestion.choice:
\code{Are you a college student?
\\ \codeIndent Yes
\\ \codeIndent No
}

\code{Are you a college student?
\\ \codeIndent Yes
\\ \codeIndent No
}

\code{Are you a college student?
\\ \codeIndent Yes
\\ \codeIndent No
}

FillInTheBlankQuestion.text: A command or instruction to the computer is a(n) \blankToFillIn.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ expression evaluates to either true or false.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ is something that must be true for something else to happen.
In Scratch, a(n) \blankToFillIn\ is a compound instruction or a construct that has other instructions inside.
The \code{forever}, \code{repeat} and \code{repeat until} Scratch instructions are each an example of a(n) \blankToFillIn\ block.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ is a place-holder for some value.
Any Scratch script in any sprite may use a(n) \blankToFillIn\ variable.
In Scratch, only one sprite may use and change any of its \blankToFillIn\ variables.
If there is more than one \blankToFillIn\ in a program, it can do multiple things at once.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ is a signal sent from one thread that can be received by all other threads.
In Excel, the letters above the grid are the column \blankToFillIn s.
In Excel, each column and row intersect in a(n) \blankToFillIn .
An Excel cell reference that adjusts with copying and pasting is a(n) \blankToFillIn\ reference.
To combine multiple Excel cells into a single cell, you \blankToFillIn\ them.
A predefined Excel formula is a(n) \blankToFillIn , and takes a value or values and performs an operation.
The inputs to a function are the \blankToFillIn s.
\blankToFillIn formatting means the cell's format depends on the value.
A(n) \blankToFillIn cell reference doesn't change when the formula is copied and pasted to another cell.
A(n) \blankToFillIn cell reference changes up to only one of the coordinates when the formula is copied and pasted to another cell.
In Excel, you can use \blankToFillIn\ seeking to find the value of a cell on which a formula depends.
Cell \blankToFillIn\ prevents other users from changing entered data and formulas.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ schedule shows periodic balances of a loan, including the amount applied to the interest and principal.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ is a series of payments at a constant interest rate.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ is an organized table of data.
A row of a database is a(n) \blankToFillIn .
Data \blankToFillIn\ ensures that values in a cell have a legitimate value.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ filters records in a database based on criteria.
An HTML \blankToFillIn\ describes an element and is written inside the \code{<} and \code{>} symbols.
A(n) \blankToFillIn\ of a tag describes a property of the corresponding element.
CSS stands for cascading \blankToFillIn\ sheets.
